PM11:06am

Banking regulators are reviewing hundreds of millions of dollars in loans made to Mr. Trump’s businesses through Deutsche Bank’s private wealth management unit, which caters to an ultrarich clientele, according to three people briefed on the review who were not authorized to speak publicly. The regulators want to know if the loans might expose the bank to heightened risks.

PM11:06am

Seems a tad over-wrought to me

11:06 am

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,344, down 74 (-5.22%), High: 1,444, Low: 1,331, Volume: 3.86m
PM11:12am

Yeah, Easyjet

PM11:12am

Q3s here https://www.invest...1707200700075665L/

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Carolyn continuing her stellar run of operational disappointment

BE11:13am

That has led EasyJet to underperform Ryanair by 100% under her tenure.

BE11:13am

Probably more if I did the chart on a total returns basis, but I don't have that handy.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

So ............ pricing guidance is downbeat.

BE11:14am

Unexpectedly. The shares had a run into these numbers on the idea that there would be an upgrade.

PM11:15am

Hence the 5% hit

11:15 am
BE11:15am

So, while the Q3 is fine, the Q4 outlook has undershot.

BE11:16am

Who can we quote here? Kepler will do.

BE11:16am

easyJet reported Q3 revenues this morning of GBP1,387m (KECH:
GBP1,334m) driven by 9.5% capacity growth, 1.1%-point load factor improvement, and a revenue per seat (RPS) at constant currency increase of 2.2%. We understand that the underlying RPS decrease was around 4%, but the company benefitted from the Easter impact in Q3. It stated that non-fuel headline cost per seat at constant currency increased by 1.6%, which is weaker than we expected (+0.5%) and the reasons mentioned for the increase are the investment in resilience (e.g. new wet leases, increase of aircraft spare parts inventories, standby aircraft availability, additional resources to perform preventative maintenance on cabins) and cost inflation, which were only partially offset by new airport deals, maintenance efficiency and up-gauging of the fleet. We understand that cost resulting from investment in resilience should remain at similar levels in the last quarter of the financial year.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

"investment in resilience" isn't a bad idea. I've not flown Easyjet for two or three years and have it take off within an hour of the scheduled departure time.

BE11:18am

Though they've probably lost me as a customer as a result so .... bit late, maybe?

BE11:18am

Back to Kepler.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The company mentions that they have now sold 80% of the H2 seats versus 78% at the same time last year; we understand that around 67% of the seats for Q4 have already been sold. The company expects an unchanged growth in capacity of 8.5% and now guides an RPS at constant currency decrease of 2% in H2 (KECH: -2%). The company reiterates its unit cost per seat excluding fuel guidance of +1% (KECH: +0.5%) and forex impact guidance; however, they reduce the fuel cost guidance by around GBP10m. The company now guides for a headline PBT of GBP380-420m, which is in line with our estimate of GBP408m and probably ahead of consensus given the probably better-than-expected Q3 performance.

BE11:19am

Note that shares up 50% or so in the year to date

BE11:20am

Which has been entirely on multiple expansion not upgrades.

11:19 am
PM11:20am

ok

BE11:20am

Ryanair's on 16.2x and 10.9x -- because it's better.

Moneysupermarket.Com Group PLC (MONY:LSE): Last: 335.60, down 23.8 (-6.62%), High: 338.20, Low: 301.00, Volume: 4.06m

PM11:23am

https://www.invest...1707200700055632L/

BE11:23am

The bad news is a caution that their cash cow of recent years seems not to be coming back.

PM11:23am

Ah, energy swtiching

PM11:23am

switching even

11:23 am

Yep, the cornerstone of the Money Saving Expert business.

BE11:24am

Collective bargaining for people who care deeply about their electricity bills.

BE11:24am

Seems the energy companies don't want to play so much any more.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

And MONY sees no chance of that business returning in the second half.

BE11:25am

We could ask obvious questions here about why, if collective switching was such a great deal for the customers, does it seem to have also been an exceptional source of revenue for MONY?

BE11:26am

But we've grumped about MONY's margins many times before. Instead, here's what's happening to forecasts.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Citi.

BE11:27am

Headline Numbers — Adj. Basic EPS increased +4% to 8.1p (Citi: 7.1p) supported by the share buyback. Revenue grew +5% to £165.3m (Citi: £165.7m). Gross Profit was flat at £120.4m (Citi: £121.5m), as gross margins fell from 76% to 73% due to higher online marketing spend. Adj. Operating Profit increased +3% to £55.2m (Citi: £47.7m). Adj. Operating Margin was down from 34.1% in 1H16 to 33.4% in 1H17, with higher amortization costs offset by lower distribution costs and controlled administration expenses. An interim dividend of 2.84p was declared (Citi: 2.97p).

BE11:28am

(@fjp73: interesting. Does that suggest the April promo failed?)

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Key KPI’s — Average monthly unique visitors to MoneySuperMarket.com were flat at 24m in 1H17. In 2Q17, Insurance revenue grew +13% to £44.1m (Citi: £44.4m) with marketing and pricing initiatives performing well in a buoyant market. Money revenues +3% to £19.5m (Citi: £19.8m) were muted by lower demand for savings products. Home Services declined -5% to £7.6m (Citi: £9.5m), due to a lack of ‘blockbuster’ collective switches in the period. MoneySavingExpert was ahead of expectations at £9.3m (Citi: £8.4m) and TravelSupermarket’s recovery continued £6.3m (Citi: £6.5m).

BE11:28am

Earnings Outlook — FY17e earnings guidance for Adj. Operating Profit to be at the lower end of consensus due to the weak trends in Energy. Consensus expectations are for £112.6m to £117.4m, with an average of £114.7m. We forecast Adj. Operating Profit of £113.0m, +5% in FY17e. Migration to the new technology platform for core channels is expected to be completed in 2H17e

BE11:29am

Implications — We expect some slight downward revision (1-3%) to consensus earnings expectations in FY17e. However, guidance may be conservative if larger scale collective switches occur in 2H17e.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Again, share ran hard into results hence the rather aggressive hit on a not terribly big disappointment.

ECB later

11:30 am

Do you want some preview grey?

BE11:31am

PM11:31am

hehe. Then here's Neil Mellow -- BNY Mellon

11:31 am
PM11:31am

The backdrop

On June 8, confirmation that neither policy normalisation nor tapering was discussed by the ECB Council left the market with the rather empty realisation that building expectations of shifts in ECB policy since late April had simply failed to materialise. Yet the tone changed on June 27, or so the market thought. As nuances in central bank communication are delivered with great care to avoid the damage that misinterpretation can wreak, it was widely felt that in his speech on that day (1), Mr Draghi took a very small step forward on the long road toward policy normalisation: accordingly, the EUR put in its largest move for a year.

PM11:31am

Whilst ECB sources informed us a day later that a nuance-savvy market had 'misinterpreted' Mr Draghi's comments (2), we suspected that the 'mix-up' reflected the ECB's alarm at the sheer scale of the EUR's ensuing rally (1.3%). The consistent caveat to the ECB's upbeat take on the Euro-zone outlook is low inflation - a caveat that is accentuated by currency strength. It is held, rightly or wrongly, that an announcement on QE is likely to come in September (and the ECB will be aware of the potential for volatility in the event it is not); but today's testimony will be most interesting given that the EUR now stands 1.3% higher than at the time of the ECB's June 28 'intervention'.

PM11:32am

Perhaps the most notable development in the interim came on July 14: sources informed Reuters that the ECB was keen to keep its asset purchases open-ended rather than setting a potentially distant date on which bond-buying will stop. One source said "... the important thing is not to pre-commit and keep it very gradual." (3)

11:32 am
PM11:32am

We will be looking to hear whether:

ECB economists have been asked to produce a list of tapering options
The ECB Council is inclined towards an open-ended QE timetable
Confidence in the Euro-zone recovery is such that Mr Draghi can all but preclude further QE
Mr Draghi reiterates the need for "persistence" in monetary policy and "prudence"
Mr Draghi is inclined to acknowledge the threat posed by EUR strength to the ECB's targets

PM11:32am

Market Behaviour

Affirmation of the policy status quo by Janet Yellen and renewed US political uncertainty is keeping firm downward pressure on the USD, and the EUR has been encroaching upon its post-2014 range highs as a result. CME data now show that non-commercial net longs in the EUR stand at 83,800k or their highest level since 2011. Certainly, the ongoing flattening of the yield curve ostensibly bodes ill for the USD, but this positioning and the potential for stiff resistance around current levels emphasises the downside risks to the EUR were the ECB seen to steer a course away from any firm commitment towards policy normalisation.

NB since the start of 2015, ECB days have been responsible for 2 of the 5 highest readings in overnight volatility in EUR/USD (the others coming on the back of the EU referendum vote in the UK, the US presidential election and comments from Janet Yellen in March 2015). This is the clearest evidence that ECB days (even more that NFP Fridays) have become the central regular event in the FX diary.

PM11:32am

There

PM11:41am

FY17 has been a busy year for Sports Direct as the group transitions towards elevating the sports retail proposition towards the long-term ambition of becoming the "Selfridges" of sports. There has been significant improvement at the senior management level and positive steps have been made in improving stakeholder engagement across all levels of the group. The strategic partnership with ASICS, the stake in Game Group and the appointment of a CFO are just three of a larger number of positive steps undertaken. The prelims have been impacted by a number of well-flagged factors but we take encouragement that the right decisions have been made to ready the business to grow from a more sustainable level.

BE11:41am

An exhausting job to be Sports Direct's shop broker, I'd imagine.

PM11:42am

New flagships outperforming: The early indications from the new generation flagship stores are positive. Two examples were provided: (1) Store X is SPD’s highest-turnover new flagship, and (2) Store Y is the lowest turnover new flagship. Both are delivering greater EBITDA than an average Sports Direct store.

STORE X (new generation flagship) - Sales area 35k sq. ft. - EBITDA 2.1m
STORE Y (new generation flagship) - Sales area 31k sq. ft. - EBITDA 1.0m
Sports Direct UK Average Store - Sales area 11k sq. ft. - EBITDA 0.5m

PM11:42am

Group revenue increased 11.7% to £3,245.3m. UK Sports Retail increased 6.3% to £2,136.4m, and International Sports Retail increased 38.0% to £665.6m. Premium Lifestyle revenue increased 11.6%, with revenue in Brands +4.1%.

The Group gross margin decreased 320 bps from 44.2% to 41.0% due to the impact of weak GBP vs. the US Dollar and an increase in provisioning for stock obsolescence which reflects risks in a fast changing market and supply chain.

Group operating costs increased 16.9% to £1,058.7m (FY16: £905.7m), which includes onerous lease and inventory provisions stemming from a review of poorly performing stores. FY17 Underlying EBITDA declined 28.5% to £272.7m, and with depreciation 54.7% higher (2017: £147.9m up from £95.6m) combined to deliver a 58.7% decrease in underlying PBT to £113.7m.

Ashtead Group PLC (AHT:LSE): Last: 1,711, up 52 (+3.13%), High: 1,719, Low: 1,698, Volume: 985.43k
BE11:53am

11:53 am
BE11:53am

BE11:53am

Here's RBC to put some numbers on it.

BE11:54am

URI Q2 results (released after the close last night) should be positive for Ashtead today. Whilst it is encouraging to see EPS beat the Street's estimate ($2.37 vs. $2.31, +2.6%) and upgraded guidance (Revenue: +3% at the low end of the guidance range and +2% at the high end; EBITDA: +4% at the low end and 1% at the top-end), it is the commentary that it has seen an improved rate trend across its business which is likely to be in focus. For Ashtead, this has been a key concern of the market, with a view that a negative rate environment inferred oversupply and therefore a slowing down of growth in the US (despite AHT demonstrating that rates have been flat and largely stable over that past 12 months). With URI seeing a rate impact of -1.2% in Q2 (pro-forma H1: -0.9%), this marks another period of sequential improvement (Q116: -2.8%; Q216: -2.4%; Q316: -1.7%; Q4; -1.8%; Q117: -1.4%).

However, as we have previously argued even with rates flat (or slightly negative), volume potential and the efficiencies of its scale should continue to drive margin growth (see chart below). We continue to like the structural story, and with potential for additional capital returns, 12.9x CY18E PE for a 2-year CAGR in EPS and DPS of 13% and 12%, respectively, looks attractive. A CY18E FCF yield of 7.4% provides further support. With positive macro data (ABI up again yesterday) and the Canadian acquisition announced, Ashtead looks to be in a good position.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

And Barclays.

BE11:55am

How relevant is all this for AHT? AHT has consistently outperformed URI over the last three years (see chart below) so in terms of what URI can directly tell us about what AHT might report in their 1Q results in September (y/e April), these results probably tell us very little; however, URI has at times been a big short-term sentiment driver of AHT’s share price so in that context the comments on improving rate trends should be well received. Ashtead is currently trading on a CY2017 EV/EBITDA of 6.2x (based on our forecasts), broadly in line with URI at 6.1x.

PM12:01pm

PM12:01pm

Think i might have to do a post on this

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

Equities have risento new all-time highs as weak USinflation data have reduced expectations of further Fed rate hikes. This has driven both bond yields and the dollar lowerand in turn EM and commodityprices higher. But thetrend might easilyreverse as the second half of thisyear progresses. This might dampen the impact of recent compelling evidence that core CPI and wage inflation seem destined to remain curiously weak throughout the remainder of this cycle.But a far bigger question is how the recent equity highs sit with our Ice Age thesis –is itdead or just sleeping?A few weeks ago, I used mostof the front page to thank clients for voting us No.1 in the Extel Survey for a record breaking 14 consecutive years. In my excitement I failedto flag that inside I had updated some of my favourite Ice Age charts with an appraisal of where we now are in the long-term secular story. I know from speaking to clientsthat most of you did not realise there was an Ice Agereprise, so Ireproduce it here on pages 3 and 4

PM12:01pm

More on that later
